text:
Hey everyone, I'm writing a piece on asynchronous meetings. 

 I want to include a step by step process on how to run one. Looking to interview anyone who has done so successfully. 

Also,  does anyone know alternative words for asynchronous? :persevere: the only synonym I've found is non real-time. 

Thank you!

elements.text:
Hey everyone, I'm writing a piece on asynchronous meetings. 

 I want to include a step by step process on how to run one. Looking to interview anyone who has done so successfully. 

Also,  does anyone know alternative words for asynchronous?

the only synonym I've found is non real-time. 

Thank you!

text: slotted-participation?

elements.text: slotted-participation?

text: from my experience, I’d say don’t bother with video (except webinars/zoom) unless you can dedicate at least 50% of a full-time employee on it. It can’t be just another thing you add onto your writers’ plate or something you do ‘when you got time’ - we have a video producer in house in my current company and that’s the only time I’ve seen a half decent video content strategy (still got lots to improve). The biggest challenges - aside from technical production (you need a good video producer/freelancer/agency if you have the budget) - are aligning expectations with your boss (“sweet, we got a lot of views, where are the leads?“) and distribution (just because you spent 10 hours producing a cool video doesn’t mean people will see it) which are similar challenges to any content type tbh

elements.text: from my experience, I’d say don’t bother with video (except webinars/zoom) unless you can dedicate at least 50% of a full-time employee on it. attachments.title: Not In Real Time: How To Run An Asynchronous Meeting
attachments.text: Running effective meetings is especially important when you’re working with a remote team. Learn how to keep everyone up to speed no matter where they're located with asynchronous meetings.

text: I work async only with all my freelance clients. When we have an async meeting, it’s generally over Slack/ Teams during our cross over time (most of my clients are UK/US). Approx 1000% more productive than real time meetings.

text: Hello everyone, it's my first time searching for a freelance content writer to help me scale the company's content efforts. We're writing long-form thought leadership pieces mostly — B2B & we're searching from someone to edit rough drafts into publishable articles. Any important things I should focus on when profiling and in setting expectations? Thanks a bunch! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hello everyone, it's my first time searching for a freelance content writer to help me scale the company's content efforts. We're writing long-form thought leadership pieces mostly — B2B & we're searching from someone to edit rough drafts into publishable articles. Any important things I should focus on when profiling and in setting expectations? Thanks a bunch!

text:
if your co has specific payment terms, make these clear up front.

If you expect images in your posts, make this clear up front.

If you have specific rules around comma usage, em dash usage, speech mark usage, make this clear up front.

If you expect _anything_, write it down so those expectations are communicated. Every freelance writers worst nightmare is the email that says "I expected this or that" but you didn't tell them this in the first place.

elements.text:

, write it down so those expectations are communicated. Every freelance writers worst nightmare is the email that says "I expected this or that" but you didn't tell them this in the first place.

text: I think a direct synonym is tough because I think async, as a culturally popular term, is rooted in its computer science origin, where it means a very specific thing (i.e. a network communication protocol).  Personally, to prevent monotony in using that term, I'd think of other characteristics of the meeting that are descriptive and use those, such as (potentially) chat-based, or turn-based, or things like that.

elements.text: I think a direct synonym is tough because I think async, as a culturally popular term, is rooted in its computer science origin, where it means a very specific thing (i.e. a network communication protocol).  Personally, to prevent monotony in using that term, I'd think of other characteristics of the meeting that are descriptive and use those, such as (potentially) chat-based, or turn-based, or things like that.

text:
Hi Alice! I’ll answer from the freelancer’s POV — make sure you’re clear on what “publishable articles” means before you set your freelancer to work on it. Have defined guidelines for a what an article should look like — structure, voice, style guide (even if it’s just “follow the AP style guide), etc.

Internally, you probably have a good understanding of what a content piece looks like. The hard part is translating that into guidelines that you can communicate to a freelancer and measure their work against.

Make sure you’re both on the same page for payment terms, deliverables and turn around time —  How much? When? How?

elements.text:

Internally, you probably have a good understanding of what a content piece looks like. The hard part is translating that into guidelines that you can communicate to a freelancer and measure their work against.

Make sure you’re both on the same page for payment terms, deliverables and turn around time —  How much? When? How?

text:
Agree. Clear instructions and a sketch of what you expect the finished product to look like will make the writer's work streamlined and seamless.

Several writers worry that editing is tougher than writing from scratch. This means 'Dos and Don'ts' have to be outlined as much as possible.

elements.text:
Agree. Clear instructions and a sketch of what you expect the finished product to look like will make the writer's work streamlined and seamless.

Several writers worry that editing is tougher than writing from scratch. This means 'Dos and Don'ts' have to be outlined as much as possible.

text:
One thing that has the potential to muddy your waters is defining what's needed to get these pieces across the finish line.  We've had a bunch of clients over the years that say, "I've got some text I want turned into a polished article/eBook."  And what they have can require three different types of work:
• A SME/writer to actually write the thing because the "draft" is just a bunch of notes or a mish-mash of emails or something.
• A developmental editor, because the prose/drafts are really rough.
• A copy editor to polish up a solid working draft.

elements.text: One thing that has the potential to muddy your waters is defining what's needed to get these pieces across the finish line.  We've had a bunch of clients over the years that say, "I've got some text I want turned into a polished article/eBook."  And what they have can require three different types of work:
A SME/writer to actually write the thing because the "draft" is just a bunch of notes or a mish-mash of emails or something.
A developmental editor, because the prose/drafts are really rough.
A copy editor to polish up a solid working draft.

text: If you go looking for one of those but really need another, it's going to be a somewhat confusing slog to find the right person.

elements.text: If you go looking for one of those but really need another, it's going to be a somewhat confusing slog to find the right person.

text:
Been there, friends. <@U01A0BPDS1X>: Yes, do/don't lose the original writer's tone and voice ought to be a clear pointer
<@U017XD7H4P7>: True. I worked with a client who used to say (among other things) "make this draft 30% better or 70% better". And of course talking at length helped me understand what he meant by "better".
I urge you to include numbers wherever possible. A lot of clarity comes in with numbers.

The rest I would probably split between organic traffic growth and social ad marketing. This is all of course based on the current situation with the pandemic, heavy shit to remote work, and brand transitions to online.

text: Hi all. What are some good productivity tools for freelance content writers? Or content people in general that I can try or explore?

elements.text: Hi all. What are some good productivity tools for freelance content writers? Or content people in general that I can try or explore?

text:
there's a bunch you can try depending on what you want to organize:
Pomodoro Timers help keep you focused as you work
Toggl and other timers help you keep track of billable hours
Trello and other task management apps help keep track of pending and active work

text: Old school, but a good ol' notebook so that you can jot down ideas when they come to mind while you're working. This allows you to document these fleeting ideas without stopping and jumping from thought-to-thought and task-to-task.

elements.text: Old school, but a good ol' notebook so that you can jot down ideas when they come to mind while you're working. This allows you to document these fleeting ideas without stopping and jumping from thought-to-thought and task-to-task.

text:
I love <http://noisli.com|noisli.com> – it is not very popular, but it offers you a text editor with softly changing color background and a set of nature/relaxing background sounds you can mix to your liking to get the atmosphere to write.

There is also optional "Pomodoro" 25min timer and save/download functions, but altogether it is more of a zen notepad when you need to really focus on your writing but enjoy doing it as well.
